e4: The CFO mentioned that small investors might be unknowingly sold short and not recognize it when they make investing decisions based solely on past financial reports. In essence, hedge funds gain a fair advantage against these unsuspecting retails in this type of setup so one could conclude that changing the existing practice would have some very unforeseen consequences that many on board members of ABC are probably quite concerned with.
e5: An ideal policy would prioritize transparency, accuracy, and fairness in reporting. It should avoid misleading practices that inadvertently benefit certain groups over others. The new policy aims to correct historical biases, acknowledging the need for trust in financial communications, particularly among retail investors who may not be attuned to market nuances.
e6: Yes, potential follow-up questions include: Can you provide data on how small investors react to changes in reporting practices? How does ABC's investor relations plan account for diverse market segments and sophisticated stakeholders? Are there considerations beyond financial impacts in evaluating the effect of changing accounting policies and subsequent communications regarding them? Any other queries may ultimately revolve around whether implementing the new policy fully reflects corporate social duties with fairness, including making informed decision-making and providing an advantage to those investors who possess this knowledge while at same making them not aware that other will gain advantages from their lack of sophistication and less awareness of trends within the financial areas that are under review in regards this existing current setup.
